description: Click-based idle game where you click on bricks to destroy them, earn currency, and purchase upgrades to progress through levels.
expectedControls: Mouse clicks on bricks and UI buttons. No keyboard controls.

inputSchema.content: This is a canvas-based game. All game content (bricks, UI) is rendered on an HTML5 canvas element. Click on coordinates within the canvas to interact with bricks. Click on UI button areas (if rendered outside canvas) to access menus. No keyboard input required.

actions.name: ClickBrick
actions.description: Click on coordinates within the canvas where bricks are rendered (center grid area, approximately 20-80% width, 15-90% height of viewport)

actions.name: BuyBall
actions.description: Click on the Buy Ball button area within the canvas (typically top-left area)

actions.name: OpenUpgrades
actions.description: Click on the Upgrades/Shop button area within the canvas (typically top-center-right area)

actions.name: OpenSettings
actions.description: Click on the Settings icon area within the canvas (typically top-right corner)

canvas.description: Main game canvas element - all game content is rendered here

currency.expectedFormat: Rendered on canvas - visual text showing currency amount

level.expectedFormat: Rendered on canvas - visual text showing level number

ballCounter.expectedFormat: Rendered on canvas - visual text showing ball count

upgradesButton.description: Rendered on canvas - button area for upgrades menu

loadingIndicators.description: Canvas element is present and visible
Grid of bricks is visible on canvas (visual check via screenshot analysis)
UI text elements (currency, level) are visible on canvas (visual check via screenshot analysis)

successIndicators.description: Bricks display numbers (health values) on canvas (verified via screenshot analysis)
Currency counter is visible on canvas and updates after clicks (verified via screenshot analysis)
Clicking canvas coordinates produces visual feedback (brick damage animation, number decrease)
Currency value increases after clicking bricks (detected via screenshot comparison)
Bricks disappear when health reaches 0 (detected via screenshot comparison)

gridBounds.description: Center grid area as percentage of viewport where bricks are located

bounds.description: Click on canvas coordinates within brick grid area (center of canvas)
bounds.note: Coordinates are relative to canvas element, not viewport

clickTargets.instructions: Find the canvas element, then click on random coordinates within the center grid area where bricks are rendered

avoidClicking: Canvas coordinates outside the brick grid area (edges of canvas)
Top UI bar area of canvas (where level/currency text is displayed)
Settings icon area (top-right corner of canvas)

expectedBehavior.immediateResponse: When clicking canvas coordinates where bricks are rendered, you should see: brick shows damage animation or number decreases visually on canvas
expectedBehavior.afterMultipleClicks: After multiple clicks on brick coordinates: currency number increases on canvas, bricks disappear when health reaches 0
expectedBehavior.progressionIndicator: Level counter (rendered on canvas) may increase after clearing enough bricks

canvasInteraction.note: All game elements are rendered on canvas. Use coordinate-based clicking within canvas bounds, not DOM element selectors

notes: Game is entirely mouse-driven - no keyboard controls needed
Primary gameplay loop: click bricks → earn money → purchase balls
IMPORTANT: This is a canvas-based game - all content is rendered on HTML5 canvas, NOT as DOM elements
QA agent must use coordinate-based clicking on canvas element, not CSS selectors
Target the canvas element, then click on coordinates within the brick grid area (center of canvas)
Brick grid area: approximately 20-80% width, 15-90% height of canvas element
Success = seeing currency increase and bricks respond to clicks (verified via screenshot analysis)
Visual validation via screenshots is REQUIRED - cannot use DOM selectors for game elements
All UI elements (currency, level, buttons) are also rendered on canvas, not separate DOM elements
